item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘The End of an Era’: 5 Takeaways
item.description: The six-part Disney+ series goes behind the scenes of the pop star’s record-breaking Eras Tour, revealing some of her creative processes and struggles.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: The End of an Era (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Swift onstage at the opening night of the Eras Tour in March 2023.

item.title: Slick Rick Likes His Tea ‘Strong and British’
item.description: “It’s the English side of me that never dies,” said the pioneering wordsmith who is celebrating 40 years of hip-hop classics like “La-Di-Da-Di.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams

item.title: From ‘Spaghetti Western’ Scores to the Opera Stage
item.description: Throughout his life, Ennio Morricone felt shunned by the classical music world. But these days his pop-culture cachet isn’t such a drawback.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A rehearsal for Ennio Morricone’s opera, “Partenope,” at the Teatro San Carlo in Naples, Italy. Although the work was composed in the 1990s, it will have its world premiere on Friday.

item.title: 15 Deep-Dive, Goodies-Filled Boxed Sets and Reissues From 2025
item.description: Some of the year’s most thrilling music was its oldest: Rock icons dug into their archives, underground ’90s rap and indie figures put out long-awaited vinyl and more.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles, Hank Shteamer, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
item.category: Music From the Land of the Sky: The 1925 Asheville Sessions (Album)
Telepathic Fish: Trawling the Early 90s Ambient Underground (Album)

item.title: Abraham Quintanilla Jr., Music Producer and Father of Selena, Dies at 86
item.description: As a teenager, he hoped to make it big in the Tejano music world. He realized that dream through his daughter.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Abraham Quintanilla Jr. in 2017. With his daughter Selena doing vocals, he turned his small family band into a Grammy-winning act, and Selena became known as the queen of Tejano music.

item.title: 41 Things That Stuck With Us in 2025
item.description: Aunt Gladys. Tyler, the Creator. That sex scene in “The Naked Gun.” These are the things Culture staffers couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: The Real Housewives of Orange County (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Neon; Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Daniel Arnold, via Loose Joints; Warner Bros.

item.title: Hanukkah Concerts With Israeli Military Cantor Raise Outcry in Amsterdam
item.description: A concert hall canceled the performance several months ago but then reached a compromise in which three concerts will be held. The bargain hasn’t satisfied critics of the events.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: Shai Abramson, the chief cantor for the Israeli military, singing in Budapest in January.

item.title: Phil Upchurch, Jazz Guitarist and Sideman to Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: A self-taught session man extraordinaire, he played with a constellation of stars, including Michael Jackson, Curtis Mayfield, Chaka Khan and Dizzy Gillespie.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Phil Upchurch in 1983, playing at the North Sea Jazz Festival in The Hague. Although he was known for his versatility across multiple genres, he considered himself a jazz player — albeit one with his own vision.

item.title: Joseph Byrd, Who Shook Up Psychedelic Rock, Dies at 87
item.description: A veteran of the Fluxus art movement, he brought an anarchic spirit to the California acid-rock scene with his band, the United States of America.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Joseph Byrd in 1970. He stood apart from his rock music peers as a former ethnomusicology instructor, an authority on early American music and a former student of John Cage, the experimental music titan.

item.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
item.description: A holiday album that cuts through seasonal glut, a late collaboration by Jim McNeely and Helmut Lachenmann’s string quartets are among the highlights.

item.title: Donald McIntyre, 91, Dies; Starred in New Vision of Wagner’s Operas
item.description: As Wotan in Patrice Chéreau’s neo-Marxist staging of the “Ring” cycle, he was part of a celebrated, polarizing moment in opera history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Donald McIntyre as Wotan and Gwyneth Jones as Brünnhilde in Wagner’s “Die Walküre” at the Royal Opera in London in 1978. Two years before, Mr. McIntyre had starred as Wotan (alongside Ms. Jones) in a groundbreaking new production of Wagner’s “Ring” operas at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany.

item.title: Sundance 2026 Lineup Includes Charli XCX and Olivia Wilde
item.description: Olivia Wilde will also appear in two films, including one she directed, and the cast of “Little Miss Sunshine” will return for its 20th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Charli XCX in “The Moment,” directed by Aidan Zamiri.

item.title: Why Return to ‘A Christmas Carol’? To Find Something New.
item.description: Popping up once a year, works like “A Christmas Carol,” “Amahl and the Night Visitors” and “It’s a Wonderful Life” help us gauge where we are in our lives.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Perelman, Ronald O, Performing Arts Center
It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play (Play)
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “A Christmas Carol” at Perelman Performing Arts Center in Manhattan.

item.title: Jubilant Sykes, Celebrated Opera Singer, Is Stabbed to Death
item.description: After the police found the Grammy-nominated performer in his home with fatal wounds, his son was taken into custody, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubilant Sykes performing as the Celebrant in “Mass,” by Leonard Bernstein, at Carnegie Hall in 2008.

item.title: Timbaland’s Latest Protégée Is an A.I. Pop Singer
item.description: The producer dreamed up TaTa Taktumi and brought her to life with help from the software Suno. She’s arriving at a fraught moment for artificial intelligence in music.
item.dc:creator: David Peisner
item.media:description: Timbaland calls TaTa Taktumi, the new pop star he is developing, a “hybrid” of work done by humans and A.I. (The person pictured here, who is indeed real, has played the role of TaTa.)

item.title: My 5 Favorite Film Scores of 2025
item.description: Nine Inch Nails’ music for “Tron: Ares,” Nala Sinephro’s compositions for “The Smashing Machine” and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails

item.title: Raul Malo, Frontman of Latin-Tinged Country Band Mavericks, Dies at 60
item.description: As the group’s singer and principal songwriter, he brought a new sound that broadened the boundaries of country music in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:description: Raul Malo performing in 2022. Sticking to tradition and one genre, he said, “just wasn’t for me.”

item.title: Best Classical Performances of 2025
item.description: Thinking outside the canon, and finding the gritty and the beautiful, within it.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone and Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:description: Nadine Sierra in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “La Sonnambula,” directed by Rolando Villazón.

item.title: Review: Two New Bach Pieces? The Real Thrill Was in the Chase.
item.description: Two workmanlike pieces by the teenage Bach had their New York premiere at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.category: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

item.title: Christine Baranski and ‘A Christmas Carol’: A Natural Pairing
item.description: On a recent recording, and in concerts this month, Baranski reads Dickens’s holiday classic with the Skylark Vocal Ensemble.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine Baranski reading from Charles Dickens’s manuscript for “A Christmas Carol” at the Morgan Library and Museum.

item.title: Katy Perry Posts Photos With Justin Trudeau Amid Romance Rumors
item.description: Ms. Perry and Mr. Trudeau, the former prime minister of Canada, posed together in photos and videos on Instagram, making them “Instagram official.”
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press, Miguel a Lopes, via EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: From Improv Class to Mayor-Elect: Zohran Mamdani’s Cultural Influences
item.description: In an interview, he revealed the Indian ragas, indie movies, comedy shows and museums in the city that stayed with him.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: In some ways, Zohran Mamdani’s cultural influences would be familiar to any New York City kid.

item.title: Best Songs of 2025
item.description: Listen to 48 tracks that broke new artists, blew apart genres and revived beloved sounds.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
